Transcript for “Is the covid-19 vaccine safe?”

If you’ve ever looked into vaccine development, you’ll hear things like “they usually take 10-15 years.” Then, how come less than a year after the start of the pandemic, there are thirteen vaccines that are approved for use, emergency or otherwise? It is right to be skeptical of the safety and efficacy of these vaccines. It is right to ask questions about whether steps were skipped, shortcuts taken, corners cut. We should answer some of these questions today.

How were the vaccines made so quickly?

We’ve had some very unique advantages with the development of the covid-19 vaccines, but it essentially boils down to excellent prior research in the medical community and an abundance of political will. The technology used in the first two vaccines approved—mRNA, or messenger ribonucleic acid—has never been used before on a large scale, which naturally invites skepticism. However, this technology has long been in development, and has been tested in clinical trials with the flu, Zika, rabies, and cytomegalovirus. Scientists knew well in advance that this technology would be helpful in a pandemic like this. mRNA allows for rapid manufacturing—in contrast to older technologies like live attenuated virus which is used in the mmr vaccine. This technique required the scientists to grow the virus for 10 years so that it could “devolve” into a strain that wouldn’t make the recipient of the vaccine sick. In an mRNA vaccine, the body itself manufactures the identifying features of the virus instead. In other words, they trick us into making the proteins rather than pre-manufacturing them. Additionally, since China released the sequenced genome soon after the virus was isolated, the scientists could start the development with few roadblocks in that department.
 
The second large factor in the speed of vaccine development was the large amount of political capital for governments to dump money into r&d of covid-19 vaccines. This allowed the developers to shorten the timeline considerably. Mind you, this does not mean the trials were rushed or the data were produced with no care. Rather, this meant that the stages of development could be staggered, so that for instance, if phase ii trials showed promising preliminary results, phase iii could be initiated.

Also, the other good thing about having popular demand is that governments can negotiate deals with pharmaceutical companies before the trials even conclude. This guarantee of purchase alleviates much of the risk with drug development, and also provides an abundance of vaccines should the trials show the vaccines to be efficacious.

Long term effects

We don’t know anything in science for 100% certainty. However, there is very little evidence pointing towards there being significant long-term side effects. But how do we know this for sure when the trails haven’t lasted for more than a few months?

Logically, we expect the significant side effects to occur within the immediate period after receiving the vaccine—and this turns out to be true. Most negative effects happen within six weeks, and this data is definitely available. All current vaccines approved for use have no significant effects in a normal adult population. Also, we’ve all heard about how the mRNA vaccines have to be stored at extremely low temperatures; this is because mRNA is extraordinarily fragile, and breaks down quite quickly in your body. This is why the scientists aren’t all that concerned about long term side effects with mRNA especially. The other ingredients and their effects are well-known, so there is little concern there.

As for the viral vector and other types, we know their methods and effects well, too. In short, if the vaccine is available, take it.
